review_title: Works for some, proceed with caution
pros: Hillel staff are engaging by default, and most are quite friendly. For remote employees, the pay scale can be very good. They hire with diversity in mind and provide basic anti-racist education opportunities to all staff. For someone seeking a network as a professional asset, a career with Hillel gives you lots of mobility. Remote workers may appreciate a flexible work schedule, but that will vary widely depending on who your teammates and supervisor are. Working in-person at the DC office means lots of face time with people in leadership positions.
cons: This is a miserable place to work if you are an early-career person. The culture of Hillel as a professional institution is workaholic and underpays and overworks employees. For those who are in their early career (many of whom have been groomed for overwork through Hillel International’s Springboard program), the norm is poorly defined job descriptions, laissez-faire supervision over skills development, and toxic positivity. Leadership are only willing to listen to recommendations to change in organizational culture after a national conversation has been started.

pros: homeowrk for money was absolutely classy. nothing to do around the office

pros: Growth and development lots of opportunities
cons: There are some downsides here

pros:
- Individual teams do great work and are supportive of each other
- HR attempting to build out a better organizational culture
- Days off for all major Jewish and non-Jewish holidays
- Solid dental insurance
- Flexible work schedule
- Friendly staff dedicated to the mission of the organization
- Good networking opportunities
cons:
- Senior Leadership is oblivious to the positive work their departments are doing
- Fired or furloughed 20% of their staff "because of the pandemic", then immediately began hiring for new positions and acquiring new departments within weeks
- Senior leadership plays favorites
- Medical insurance is terrible
- Pay is below average
- Not much room for upward mobility

pros:
- decent benefits (cell phone reimbursement, comp time, vacation time)
- flexible schedule
- wonderful emotional support from sensitive coworkers
cons:
This was my first peek into a truly dysfunctional nonprofit work environment. We would have weekly meetings brainstorming how to get more engaged college students, usually concluding that their parents should have raised them more Jewish from birth. I was hired and was never given a work space. I worked from home 6/7 months I was employed. Worse off, the students I was supposed to be engaging didn't have a traditional hang space, either. We would meet in drafty Starbucks and I'd end up apologizing there was nowhere else to go.  It was hard to sell them on the idea of Hillel with no product to show. 

- no leadership/unified vision
- unattainable questions and goals posed like: "how do we make Hillel cool?", "where are all the Jewish students?"
- tension/toxic atmosphere created by bleak conditions and unhappy staff and students

review_title: It is a fun place to work in the day to day, but hard to imagine a future
pros: Lots of young people mean you make a ton of new friends your very first day. No two days are the same. Lots of free food, events, community. Every Jewish holiday off.
cons:
Can feel very chaotic and disorganized at times. Low pay, as it is a non-profit. 
A feeling that 20-somethings are just brought on to work as hard as possible and then sent off after a couple years. An environment where if you make a mistake or go against the grain everyone is talking about it.

review_title: Learn a Lot and Sacrifice Personal Life
pros:
- Learning experience is out of this world, but be prepared to work for it
- PTO is great and depending on your ED you may get additional days
- Working on campus can be really fun
- Often times you are surrounded by food
- Decent benefits
cons:
- No upward growth for personal careers, if you are coming right out of college expect to be here about 2-3 years
- ED's never give up their positions as long as they are meeting some Hillel standards
- The community is so tightly knit that once you leave you should expect everyone will be talking about it
- Working 60-80 hours is not unusual
- Weekends, holidays, and late nights, expect to be working all of it
- Each Hillel is run differently and International holds no standards around success which helps align a Hillel vision forward
- Low pay

job_title: Campus Entrpreneur in New York, NY
pros: flexible schedule, meet new people, create initiatives you love, get reimbursed for events you create, great community, salary for doing things that feel natural!, all -expense trip paid to go to annual Hillel nation conference (very fun!!!), get your friends to top of the Birthright list
cons: have to use an outdated (or at least was for me) database called REACH, have to meet minimum amount of new people and log them into database which can sort of trivialize value of relationships

review_title: Special place but Very disorganized and hierarchical
pros: Being on campus at UM is spectacular. The campus is beautiful. Also working directly with college students is fun and a critical opportunity to have a major impact on their life.
cons: The board is in charge, yet almost none of them have any real relationship to umiami or hillel. They're like a hidden dictatorship refusing to listen to feedback. There is no strategy in place. And trying to create a strategy is impossible because leadership is constantly changing depending on the mood of the board. Total disservice to the students.

pros:
Great mission and many people who are committed to achieving it
Days off on all Jewish holy days and off early on Friday for Shabbat 
Decent healthcare
cons:
I wouldn’t recommend that anyone go to work here. 

There is no attention to career trajectory and not much room for growth within the organization unless you are favored by someone high up. 
 
It is a top heavy organization where only senior level employees are appreciated and are compensated fairly 

Extreme lack of transparency exists around majority of things. Very frustrating how many convos take place that staff are uninformed on

Everything moves slow. So much bureaucracy and red tape

review_title: Hillel is a great place to work
pros: My team has a great staff dynamic; there are a lot of perks (travel to USA locations and abroad, mostly to Israel); ability to make a difference in students' lives; generous vacation time; huge network of colleagues all over the world; variety of conferences to attend
cons: It's a nonprofit, so individual Hillel's can be poorly managed and unorganized; almost no work/life balance as your life is mostly the work; you're dealing with tempermental, judge-y college students; sometimes unable to do the work you want to do due to bureaucratic and administrative constraints at whichever university you are working at.

review_title: Over worked, underpaid and no support
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Great place for an entry level position to learn group and engagement work with college students. You will work 12 hour days, seven days a week but will get great programming and organizational experiences.
cons: Hi burnout. Low wages. Hard to balance personal and work life. Very hard for staff with families.

review_title: Changed my undergrad experience from dull to amazing
pros:
-met a lot of great people
-got the opportunity to travel with new friends
-created a community vibe that made the transition from home to college dorms more comfortable
-
cons: -anti Jewish feel on campus at times...or at least anti Israel

pros: Many true entry level positions (no 3 years experience required) are available for college grads and early career people. Innovative and mission-based work. You can feel the impact of your projects.
cons: Like many nonprofits, cross-department communications and general processes could use improvements. As a innovating organization, some items fall through the cracks as we strive forward.

pros: Program colleagues are smart and driven, and the impact of your work is felt across the Jewish world. There is no place to have more positive influence on the future of the Jewish community than at Hillel.
cons: The hierarchical organization is in flux, in need of reorganization and better HR structure at the SIC and in the field to improve performance.

review_title: Being a student worker at Hillel is amazing!
pros: Very flexible, understanding and a fantastic team to work with. This is by and far my favorite job I've ever worked. I am happy to come to every shift I work here.
cons: The hours are limited due to need and work study restrictions so it is hard to live on without secondary income from some source. Can be left with a lot of idle time.

pros:
Working with students is rewarding.  Students work with you to plan and are willing to volunteer for different projects and events.  
It is fun to work on a college campus
cons: Long hours, low-pay, working every Friday for Shabbat and other Jewish holidays, quantity over quality with engagement tracking.

pros: Fairly easy job duties and the manager was very easy going and nice about anything coming up. I was able to miss a good amount of work days and be able to work from home if it was an emergency.
cons: Not much room to grow here or increase my salary. The work was very repetitive and got to be boring after a few months.

pros: There are great coworkers, the benefits are good and there is a decent amount of vacation time. Challenging work opportunities.
cons: Lack of communication sometimes from both department managers and senior management about department and organization goals to the rest of the staff..

review_title: Most Hillels are great, mine is not.
pros: The students, the learning experience and the quality of work that is done.  It's an amazing organization with the right school.
cons: Working with a Board of Directors. Some Executive Directors should not be in their positions, which makes it very difficult, and the salary is not fair to amount of work that is done.

review_title: Good first job, limited room for growth
pros: Vacation time, flexibility of schedule, atmosphere
cons: Salaries, benefits, work-life balance are very tough, especially for someone just moving to the area. It's very hard to negotiate salaries, based on which campus you work on, because they just don't invest the $ in their junior staff... partly because most of the time they just don't have it.

review_title: Hillel needs to increase salary and professional development opportunities
pros: Usually people who work for Hillel are working in something they are passionate about and that makes going to work every day more exciting.
cons: The salary for mid management is pretty horrible and varies widely from campus to campus.

review_title: I had mostly positive experience at Hillel - many excellent people work there.

cons: Minimal opportunity for advancement.  No comp time or flex time.  Telecommuting discouraged.

pros: Staff was friendly and team-oriented.

pros: I loved the students I got to interact with everyday. There was ample opportunity to complete a wide range of tasks.
